text: I'm Zane Reynolds I'm the manager of the
data engineering team at torque robotics
torque robotics was originally founded
in 2005 and then later in 2019 was
acquired by Daimler Trucks auto group
and since then has been laser focused on
building an L4 autonomous truck solution
the autonomous Trucking space has such
high volumes of data they had all of
their data and all of the compute power
on-prem it was a big expensive system
that sat in one location and if they
sent a vehicle to another area to drive
they would have to ship the data back
like physically ship drives back and try
to load it onto the system and we knew
that in order to
fulfill the mission for Daimler we're
going to need a lot more scale we moved
all of our data to the cloud my team's
primary
product to the rest of torque is a data
lake so we initially started with trying
to move our data from those on-prem
services to S3 and we also wanted to
start collecting the data directly from
the vehicles to S3 as well so that was
goal number one get everything into S3
so to do that we migrated our data from
on-prem using snowballs we bulk migrated
a lot of our existing data to S3 that
way so trucks would go out on a drive
they come back basically pull out a
canister of these hard drives plug it
into a node that streams everything to
S3 as quickly as possible that works
really well for us because we have a
couple of primary distributed sites so
all that data is getting funneled in
once it's there we do a process to make
that data usable as part of a data Lake
which is unpacking a lot of the data
from that point we used Blake formation
to create the data Lake that gives us
the central catalog and once things are
in Lake formation they connect really
well to lots of other tools and services
so sagemaker is one that we use quite a
bit for for machine learning and model
training we also use Quick site for
reporting so we have a lot of different
use cases I think that's where the data
lake is such a cool thing for torque to
be able to have because lots of
different use cases variable access
patterns and this gives us a nice
flexible way to provide the data that's
needed to all the different teams if
you're Fleet operations and you want to
report on
what percentage of the time were we in
robotic mode on this section of Highway
in June of this year you can do that if
you're a machine learning team like a
perception team and you want to find
examples for your training set where the
road has extreme curvature you can do
that as well and all these capabilities
weren't there prior to building the data
Lake you only had that role that raw
binary compressed data specifically
around S3
we have been impressed with how simple
and performant it really is it was a
central component to the data Lake that
we have built and to all the operations
that we built on top of it and we don't
have to worry about S3 the benefit that
we really get is that every team can
move faster and can focus on the work
that's
differentiated work as compared to you
know building the infrastructure that's
needed to answer those questions and we
want to send the vehicles out into the
world to experience the world to see
what the different situations are
weather conditions different road
conditions are there emergency vehicles
are there cars on the shoulder Etc so
the more the trucks can be out in the
world and sense the things around them
the better the algorithms can be to
drive those trucks and then the safer
the product will be at the end I think
having the data available in the way
that we have it through a data Lake
created so many new capabilities it made
a big difference to I think every team
every team is using the data Lake now it
helps
everyone move faster and can focus a
little bit more on the mission that
they're trying to solve
